paper.title: SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccines sensitize tumours to immune checkpoint blockade

core_question: Investigates whether intratumoral delivery of an mRNA vaccine can create an interferon-rich inflammatory state that improves sensitivity to anti-PD-L1 therapy.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Mouse efficacy cohort (combination therapy)
datasets_or_cohorts.sample_size_or_observations: 78 tumor-bearing mice pooled across repeat experiments
datasets_or_cohorts.description: 78 tumor-bearing mice in murine tumor models with intratumoral mRNA vaccine and anti-PD-L1 combinations.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Mouse control cohort (vaccine only, ICI only, and vehicle)
datasets_or_cohorts.sample_size_or_observations: 84 tumor-bearing mice pooled across matched controls
datasets_or_cohorts.description: 84 tumor-bearing mice in matched controls for vaccine only, ICI only, and vehicle.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human retrospective metastatic cohort
datasets_or_cohorts.description: A retrospective cohort of 130 metastatic patients receiving ICI treatment, compared by prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination status.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human vaccinated subgroup
datasets_or_cohorts.description: A subgroup of the human retrospective cohort of 43 patients who had received prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human unvaccinated subgroup
datasets_or_cohorts.description: A subgroup of the human retrospective cohort of 87 patients who had not received prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination.

major_limitations: The human analysis is retrospective and non-randomized; residual confounding is likely.
Vaccination timing relative to ICI initiation varied across patients.
Tumor-type mix and treatment-history heterogeneity limit direct causal interpretation.
Mouse model effects may not map one-to-one to all human tumors.
Some mechanistic readouts were strongest in specific model systems rather than uniformly across all tested settings.
